text:
Hi, I'm playing with Turing and I want to create a model for ridge regression solution via HMC. My resource is in the picture. I can't find a way to do this and compose `@model`. I posted my question here: <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/ridge-regression-using-turing-jl/52378>

Is there anyone who could help me? Is it even possible to use HMC for this kind of problem? Thanks in advance for any suggestions :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Hi, I'm playing with Turing and I want to create a model for ridge regression solution via HMC. My resource is in the picture. I can't find a way to do this and compose
@model
. I posted my question here:
Is there anyone who could help me? Is it even possible to use HMC for this kind of problem? Thanks in advance for any suggestions
I managed to do at least this:

text: But the result is only a point estimate of parameters (alpha should be sampled from latest theta...)

text:
I tried 1000 iterations, too, but I get a warning for each iteration and it still has only one value in the vector for all parameters
```Warning: The current proposal will be rejected due to numerical error(s).
│   isfinite.((θ, r, ℓπ, ℓκ)) = (true, false, false, false)```
I don't know what exactly causes the warning and how to improve it...

text: Sorry, I'm away from a machine at the moment and can't help as much as I'd like.

elements.text: Sorry, I'm away from a machine at the moment and can't help as much as I'd like.

text: To me it seems, you already used the two conditional distributions (second and third point in your reference) in your Turing model. However, the model should just be based on the joint likelihood (first point), and then you can exploit the conditional distributions by using `GibbsConditional` in your `Gibbs` sampler.

elements.text: To me it seems, you already used the two conditional distributions (second and third point in your reference) in your Turing model. However, the model should just be based on the joint likelihood (first point), and then you can exploit the conditional distributions by using
GibbsConditional
in your
Gibbs
sampler.

It's a lot simpler than your model but doesn't have the same nice prior structure you have above.

text: Interesting that raw HMC didn't work, maybe it just needed a smaller step size or something.

elements.text: Interesting that raw HMC didn't work, maybe it just needed a smaller step size or something.

text:
Yes, I've seen the example, I tried it and it works. Unfortunately, this is a school project and I need to use the same structure for two models - Gibbs and HMC and compare them. I'll try a few other step sizes for HMC and see if I can get it working.

Still, is there a possibility to sample two parameters that are dependant on each other? For Gibbs I can simply create a loop like this:
```α0 = 0.5
θ0 = [1 1 1];
γ = 0;
δ = 0;
d = 3

iter = 1000
α = zeros(iter+1)
θ = zeros(iter+1,3)
α[1] = α0
θ[1,:] = θ0

for i in 1:iter
    E = (X'*X)^(-1)*X'*y
    D = Symmetric((X'*X + α[i]*I)^(-1))
    θ[i+1,:] = rand(MvNormal(E,D))

    a = δ + d/2
    b = γ + norm(θ[i+1,:])^2
    α[i+1] = rand(Gamma(a,b))
end```
θ[i+1] is sampled from α[i] and α[i+1] from θ[i+1]...

elements.text:
Yes, I've seen the example, I tried it and it works. Unfortunately, this is a school project and I need to use the same structure for two models - Gibbs and HMC and compare them. I'll try a few other step sizes for HMC and see if I can get it working.

Still, is there a possibility to sample two parameters that are dependant on each other? For Gibbs I can simply create a loop like this:

α0 = 0.5
θ0 = [1 1 1];
γ = 0;
δ = 0;
d = 3

iter = 1000
α = zeros(iter+1)
θ = zeros(iter+1,3)
α[1] = α0
θ[1,:] = θ0

for i in 1:iter
    E = (X'*X)^(-1)*X'*y
    D = Symmetric((X'*X + α[i]*I)^(-1))
    θ[i+1,:] = rand(MvNormal(E,D))

    a = δ + d/2
    b = γ + norm(θ[i+1,:])^2
    α[i+1] = rand(Gamma(a,b))
end
θ[i+1] is sampled from α[i] and α[i+1] from θ[i+1]...

text: The iterative dependency is only introduced when you explicitly write down the conditional distributions. For non-Gibbs samplers you have to implement the probabilistic model of the joint distribution that is given in the first equation in your reference.

elements.text: The iterative dependency is only introduced when you explicitly write down the conditional distributions. For non-Gibbs samplers you have to implement the probabilistic model of the joint distribution that is given in the first equation in your reference.

text:
I.e.
```model function linreg(X, y, δ, γ, ω)
    α ~ Gamma(δ, γ)
    θ ~ MvNormal(size(X, 2), sqrt(inv(α)))
    y ~ MvNormal(X * θ, sqrt(ω))
end```

elements.text: I.e.

model function linreg(X, y, δ, γ, ω)
    α ~ Gamma(δ, γ)
    θ ~ MvNormal(size(X, 2), sqrt(inv(α)))
    y ~ MvNormal(X * θ, sqrt(ω))
end

text:
You can exploit the analytical conditional distributions in the Gibbs sampler with `GibbsConditional`:
```julia> cond_θ = let X=X, y=y
           c -> begin
               θ_hat = X \ y
               Σ = Symmetric(inv(X' * X + c.α * I))
               return MvNormal(θ_hat, Σ)
           end
       end

julia> cond_α = let X=X, δ=δ, γ=γ, d=d
           c -> begin
               return Gamma(δ + d / 2, γ + sum(abs2, c.θ))
           end
       end

julia> sample(linreg(X, y, δ, γ, ω), Gibbs(GibbsConditional(:θ, cond_θ), GibbsConditional(:α, cond_α)), 1_000)```

elements.text: You can exploit the analytical conditional distributions in the Gibbs sampler with
GibbsConditional

julia> cond_θ = let X=X, y=y
           c -> begin
               θ_hat = X \ y
               Σ = Symmetric(inv(X' * X + c.α * I))
               return MvNormal(θ_hat, Σ)
           end
       end

julia> cond_α = let X=X, δ=δ, γ=γ, d=d
           c -> begin
               return Gamma(δ + d / 2, γ + sum(abs2, c.θ))
           end
       end

julia> sample(linreg(X, y, δ, γ, ω), Gibbs(GibbsConditional(:θ, cond_θ), GibbsConditional(:α, cond_α)), 1_000)

text:
For other samplers you would just call
```julia> sample(linreg(X, y, δ, γ, ω), NUTS(), 1_000)```
or
```julia> sample(linreg(X, y, δ, γ, ω), MH(), 1_000)```
etc.

elements.text: For other samplers you would just call
julia> sample(linreg(X, y, δ, γ, ω), NUTS(), 1_000)
or
julia> sample(linreg(X, y, δ, γ, ω), MH(), 1_000)
etc.

text: Isn't ridge regression provably equivalent to standard Bayesian linear regression with a multivariate normal prior on theta?

elements.text: Isn't ridge regression provably equivalent to standard Bayesian linear regression with a multivariate normal prior on theta?

text: i.e. exactly the example <@U8T9JUA5R> posted. I'm just confused by the apparent dependence of alpha on the norm of theta, as this does not appear in the model specification.

elements.text: i.e. exactly the example
posted. I'm just confused by the apparent dependence of alpha on the norm of theta, as this does not appear in the model specification.

text: It's only an implicit dependency - it appears when you write down the conditional distribution of alpha for this model, given theta, X, and y.

elements.text: It's only an implicit dependency - it appears when you write down the conditional distribution of alpha for this model, given theta, X, and y.

text:
Yeah, right, I see that now. Thanks!

Also, I don't see `GibbsConditional`  in the docs on <http://turing.ml|turing.ml>. Am I missing something?

elements.text:
Yeah, right, I see that now. Thanks!

Also, I don't see
GibbsConditional
in the docs on
turing.ml
. Am I missing something?

text: No, IIRC it's only documented in the docstring currently: `?GibbsConditional` The webpage has not been updated with the more recent features and internal changes, also because there is some ongoing restructuring which will it make easier to contribute and update tutorials and update the documentation in the corresponding packages (many things are actually not implemented in Turing.jl itself).

elements.text: No, IIRC it's only documented in the docstring currently:
?GibbsConditional

The webpage has not been updated with the more recent features and internal changes, also because there is some ongoing restructuring which will it make easier to contribute and update tutorials and update the documentation in the corresponding packages (many things are actually not implemented in Turing.jl itself).
